author: RAYoung

description.text:
Here is my take of the Naze32 case. I try to make it as light weight as possible Print a copy of Case_Lower.stl
If your 6x3 way and 3x2 way pins are horizonal (ie. 90 degree pins) , print Case_Upper_H_Pins.stl
If your 6x3 way and 3x2 way pins are vertical (ie. straight pins) , print Case_Upper_V_Pins.stl
If your 6x3 way pins are vertial and 3x2 way pin are horizonal then print Case_Upper_H1_V2_Pins.stl Shape the screw holes of the upper case with a 3mm drill bit
Shape the screw hole of the lower case with a 2.5mm drill bit then tape the holes with a M3x0.5 Tap.
Put your naze32 flight controller inside and screw them together with nylon M3 x 12 countersunk machined screws. Of course you can use metal screws if you don't have nylon ones.

This is a cutomizable cupholder for wheelchair users.
This comes in two parts, the cup and the grip.
You have to glue the two parts, there are a million ways to glue them, I've had luck with epoxy or abs mixed with acetone.
I designed twelve different cups, and a few different grips in different width. For the cups, you can print any one of them you like, some are easier to print than others, some are stronger than others. But as you can see in the pictures, all are printable. For the grips, I made several of them for different widths of armrests, the sizes range from 50 mm to 80 mm in 5 mm increments. Each of the sizes has 3 different designs.
And I made a customizable one which you can find here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1097204.
Unfortunately I'm just a begginner in Openscad so I couldn't design a nice looking customizable grip. If anyone wants to give me a hand and remix it, you're more than welcome. Alternatively, you can just print the grip and glue whatever you want on it. The grip part is also a modular fastening method to the armrest. If you end up making this please post a picture, I would love to see them in use ! I'm posting more details as I finish printing all the prototypes.

I uploaded this design in the fashion accessory category on purpose. The whole point of this project is to use design to help people with disabilities feel better about assistive technology. Just like eyeglasses have come a long way from a medical apparatus to a fashion accessory, I hope to help do the same with wheelchair accessories. I am working on several other accessories and modular design projects for wheelchair users, these cupholders are more a proof of concept than anything else.
In the next days I'll be uploading a link to a website where I'm talking a bit more about all this.

As an entry for the Assistive Technology challenge, this design is meant to attach to the end of the tubes used to remove excess saliva from handicapped students mouths. It is an attachment that can go onto the already existing tubes, but will provide a more comfortable experience than the normal suction tubes.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

I spoke with a teachers aid in a high school special education classroom about what would be needed to help make the lives of the students easier. She responded with the insight on how the tubes are uncomfortable when saliva is needed to be collected. This design will provide the effect of a pacifier while the process is being done.

print_settings.Resolution:: 0.1 for most of parts, 0.05 for radar dome

title: Heavy Hydra air defense turret with posable radar

description.text:
So, this model originally had a few problems, in my opinion. The embedded radar didn't make a lot of sense and it made it harder to cleanup after printing. The gun breeches were separate, to be glued afterwards, so I thought, why not print them as one part? That helps avoid potential misalignments and produces a stronger part overall.
So I fixed those problems and remixed it. What to print:
4x gun barrel
1x gun breech left
1x gun breech right
4x gun magazine
2x gun swivel
1x radar base
1x radar top
1x turret panel reviewed
1x turret panel 2
1x turret reviewed
1x turret swivel
1x turret vision

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 for most of parts, 0.05 for radar dome

Infill:

15% is enough

Notes: Only the breech might need support, due to an overhanging part in the top end. No need to print mirrored parts.

Cleaning and priming These steps are made with the model UNASSEMBLED Step 1: Clean model with x-acto knife
Step 2: Sand model with coarse sandpaper, can be wet sanded.
Step 3 (optional): Apply filler to whole model and then sand again, with progressively finer sandpapers.
Step 4: Apply primer paint, preferably grey to better see imperfections. Apply filler and sand again if needed.
Step 5: Assemble the model and bask in it's glory
Step 6 (optional): Paint with acrylics.
Step 7: ?????
Step 8: Profit
Software Modelled in Rhino after the original components

title: Prusa Y Belt tensioner for SAE Hardware and T-5 belt

description.text:
Same design as chrille but modifies to use 6-32 nuts and bolts.
Update: Added belt attachment with teeth for the other end of the y-belt.

Non-tension end(back of y-carriage):
  • Place the part with teeth cutouts facing up and line up with the holes on the y-carriage.
  • Lay the belt teeth into the teeth cutouts.
  • Install the retainer cap with the notch facing down.
  • Install the 6-32 washers and bolts and tighten, this does not have to be super tight since the teeth are doing the work, not the clamping force.
    • Tensioner end(front of y-cariage):
  • Insert captive 6-32 nut
  • Bolt the two parts to the plate, so the bottom part has the belt slot facing down towards the plate and the captive nut is facing towards the middle of the plate. The top piece should have the teeth facing down, grabbing the teeth of the belt.
  • Screw in the 6-32 tension bolt (I used a 1" bolt)
  • Adjust the bolt till you get the tension just right

author: howardww

description.text:
To assemble -
line hold on handle up with the holes on the base
push pin through it and test it to make sure it works
to attach a knife to it put the knife in the slot and secure it using rubber bands or zip ties How it works -
When it is put together you can put objects in the indented area to cut. There are indents to make it grip a bit better so you can get a better cut. To cut you put your object in the middle and push the handle down until it cuts through the object. This is meant to make it easier to cut objects you might normally have trouble with. note
The I added the knife STL if you want to download it but I don't recommend using it to cut food with the holder. I made it just to show how it holds the knife.

How I designed it - I found Isarts3d's knife support and thought it was a good idea but I wanted to try and improve it. I looked at his pictures and made a rough model of something somewhat like his. I then re designed it adding grips for thee food, a reshaped handle and indent for the knife, so it can go father down (so handle doesn't hit). I also changed how the knife attaches so it stays on good and can still be easily removed while being able to use a wide variety of knives.

This is a simple soldering iron I made as an upgrade to the radio shack model which just seemed underpowered and well.... lame. I made a slot for a lipo battery and the same switch and as the light wasn't really useful to me anyway, I left it out. One could easily be added. Print vertically and drill the holes through. Drill the top hole to fit your light bulb socket and the side to fit your button of choice. The bottom hole should fit the battery snugly already. Positive to tip of the socket, from there to the switch and from there to the battery. Negative to the screw of the socket, and directly to the battery. If you ream the holes properly, everything should fit snugly with no glue. The second file contains the battery grip as well so you can fully insert the battery. Be gentle with the button as this iron is overvolted slightly and will burn out if you hold it down too long! Batteries

title: Z Axis Restraint for Pangu i3

description.text:
Restraining the Z axis threaded rods at the ends can help reduce forces caused by wobble in the threaded rods being communicated down the X axis to the print head.
When taken in addition to other measures such as thing 1077863 Z axis wobble can be virtually eliminated. Inspired by thing 9864 this is a Z Axis constraint for the Pangu i3 variant of the Prusa i3 marketed by rp3d.com. Pangu i3 has the Z axis smooth rods sitting flush with the laser cut frame and a cap over the top fixed by M3 bolts. This Z restraint replaces the cap and grips the 6mm threaded rod above the laser cut frame using a 626 bearing. Some shrink wrap over the top of the threaded rod will help it fit the bearing more snugly. A scad file is provided, so it could be adapted to fit other printers.

description.text:
Customizable wheels. Variables include:
  • outer_diameter: overall size of wheels
  • wall_thickness: thickness of the outer rim and hub
  • thickness: width of the wheel
  • spokes: number of spokes (large number produces solid wheel)
  • spoke_thickness
  • spoke_width
  • hub_thickness
  • axle
  • number of wheels to print
    • The default wheel is 5 cm and fits nicely on a barbecue skewer axle (~4mm). A set of four weighs in at 9 grams at 5 percent infill (9.1 for 10 percent = no difference). These were designed for balloon powered cars so weight was a big factor. The set of eight fits the build plate of a flashforge creator pro perfectly. Prints in 2.5 hours with default settings. Known issues / further improvements:
  • Spokes are cubes so width is limited
  • Only one spoke style
  • Round axle is the only option at this time
  • Code thrown together quickly - not the prettiest

author: Ac5EqC

description.text:
A watercolor kit that holds half-pan solid watercolor pigments that can be found at any art supply store.
It also has mixing pans and slots for retractable watercolor brushes.
Designed using OpenJSCAD.org
Latest Source code for model is here: https://github.com/mscherotter/wcpal

Use construction marking flags for hinge Cut construction marking flags (found at hardware store) to length for hinge pin. A strand of 1.75mm PLA filament will also work as a hinge pin.
I am looking into methods to keep the hinge wire from falling out.

Design process Starting out with a design in my journal, I created a quick model using 3D Builder, the free 3D Modeling software on Windows 10.
Wanting to try something new, I used the online design tool OpenJSCAD.org to design a parametric-defined model. Here is an example of how I rounded the corners:
// Generate a quarter-round used to radius the edges (4mm radius)
function corner() {
return color("white", cube({ size: [4, 4, 140] })
.translate([0, 0, 0])
.subtract(cylinder({ r: 4, h: 140 }))
.rotateY(90));
} and then I subtract the corner from the model after rotating it:
model.subtract(corner().rotateX(-90)) Initial design in my journal Buidling the design in 3D Builder as a first draft.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7eIslDl2mos

title: Low Polygon Mask easy breathing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Remixed the thin version by adding mouth and nose holes so you can breath and slits on the sides to add an elastic head strap. Lastly this is resized to fit 150mm x 150mm (6x6) print beds. Perfect for the Printrbot Simple Metal.

After printing the remixed version and trying it on, it ended up being too small in some parts on my face. The original mask has sullen cheeks and narrow temples, which made the fit tight and very uncomfortable. Also, the breathing holes weren't big enough and still felt constricting wearing it. So I completely rebuilt the mask from scratch, using the original as a template.
This new version is wider on the jaw and cheeks. The thickness of the entire model is now 2mm. Previous version was not even on some spots, so a bit of filament savings. The eyes are no longer squinting which helps with visibility and the eyelashes sweeping on the edges. The mouth is now open with a slight grin and you can breath easy or stick your tongue out. :}~
Lastly, I added a buckle for the head strap. The strap should be about 1/2 inch in width.
I'll keep the remixed version on here, but I recommend Version 2 since it's a complete remodel and will most likely fit better. And it still fits on a 6" x 6" bed.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: I recommend printing the mask in PLA in case it feels a bit tight. PLA can be heat molded to fit better. No need for supports. I printed my mask with natural PETG using honeycomb infill. Looks pretty neat. Took about 7 and half hours to print.
Most likely you'll need to cut off some hanging strands due to the over hangs on the eyes and mouth if you use a harder filament. Should print out pretty cleanly.

description.text: Blobbies are little creatures that are always happy and excited. They are not capable of any other emotional state. Even when a fellow Blobby gets crushed in front of their googly eyes they can't help but cheer in joyful excitement.

Doesn't Matter

Notes: They print easy without any support. If you print the version with seperate eyes you might need a raft or first layer support for printing the eyes. If you like to print them bigger or smaller there are also versions of the eyes and pupils with the tolerance for 150% and 75%. The 150% version still works fine for a 200% print though.

You will have to push the eyes in with some force but be careful not holding it on the arms or hands while doing so or they might snap. The optional pupils can be put in the holes of the eyes and glued on.
I used a aceton vapor finish for my ABS printed Blobbies. Just soaked some paper towels with aceton and hanged them on the side inside a non ABS plastic box. Put the Blobbies inside with the lid on top and waited a few hours til the vaporized aceton reacted with the ABS and with it made it smooth. The eyes I have sprayed additionally with clear coat.

Note: This has been recently updated so if you have downloaded a previous part prior to 12/3/15, please delete it and re-download the parts so you can have to updated version.
The Assistive Rotating Pill Container was specific designed to allow many different people with different kinds of disabilities to be able to easily use the pill container. It's also an improvement to the pill containers that have snap-on covers that may be hard to remove for some people as well as being hard to get the pills out. The container is shaped as a heptagon for each day of the week and as you rotate the pill container, the pills in the slot for the next day will fall out onto a plate that can easily be grabbed. The container is simply rotated by spinning the top or sides of the design clockwise. This allows people with limited hand or wrist mobility to easily rotate it to get the pills that they may need for the day. The top of the container, which is the part that allows you to spin it, has openings to allow you to easily put pills in by dropping it in the day of the week that you need it. The pill container consists of four parts which are individually 3D printed and assembled. The only thing that you need is a few drops of glue or adhesive to hold a couple of the parts together in a very simple and explained 5 step process. It's also designed so that the parts already interlock with each other so you can even use plain Elmer glue to do the job. Not only can people with disabilities use this product. Any can print it out and use it as a pill container. Not only is it functional but it also looks really neat as well. The Assistive Pill Container is very compact, yet extremely functional. Since it's so compact it doesn't require much plastic filament (3.63 cubic inches) in order to print out making it very cheap as well. There are absolutely no pill container that can compare to this one, especially for the disabled.

I designed this at my school in my Engineering II and Tech Ninja classes as an assignment. Every student in the Engineering II class was given time to research and come up with a design to make. I also was allowed to work on the design in my Tech Ninja class. The Tech Ninja class is a new class that a teacher in my middle school ran that invited kids that were motivated to go beyond any other class with technology and learn much more about different technologies. The first year I have moved to high school they didn't have a Tech Ninja class but this year my Engineering II teacher took up the job to run the class. In my design I chose to start with Part 2 before I moved onto any of the other parts. I worked off of Part 2 went on to design Part 1, Part 3, and then Part 4. While working on the different parts I had to make many various changes to the design to improve the design and make it work better meaning that the parts fit together better and the have a less chance at breaking. While making the design I also wanted to make it small and compact so that it didn't take much space and so that it was cheaper to print. I was originally planning on having lids on top of the container but the idea was scrapped for a couple of reasons. One of the reasons is that it would be difficult for the disabled to remove it and put it back on to put pills into the container, defeating one of the major points of the pill case. Also, due to the container's shape I was having some issues making a good cover and if I were to make one it probably wouldn't have worked too well. The program I used in the whole process of designing and making the pill container was Solidworks. The cover photos of the pill container was made using the render tool in Solidworks as well as all of the other photos under the Assembly Instructions. Version 1.0 Version 1.0 was my first design on the pill case and was really successful. When I got it 3D printed there were some flaws however. One of the main flaws was that when I was making it in Solidworks I was using exact measurements for when I had to connect parts. Therefore, many of the parts did not go together because they were too tight or just too big. Another flaw was that the bottom of Part 2 was very thin and looked as if you could easily break it. Finally, a minor flaw was that the plate that the pill falls onto wouldn't have done a good job with holding the pills. The pills would have likely just fell out of it. Picture of Version 1.0 Assistive Rotating Pill Container Version 1.1 Version 1.1 has the same features of Version 1.1 but added a neat option on how to print it out. The option is printing Part 3 with clear plastic to make it see through. This allows you to see the pills easier and it makes it look better in my opinion. Please note that this is completely optional. Picture of Version 1.1 Assistive Rotating Pill Container Version 2.0 In version 2 I fixed a lot of issues that I have found after printing version 1. All of the places that parts go together are now fixed so they will fit correctly now when printed out. While correcting that flaw I also made it easier to assemble Parts 1 & 2. I also tried to do my best to make sure the pill case can easily spin with no problem. Another issue that was fixed is that I added more material to the bottom of Part 2 so it won't break. Finally, I increased the wall size of the plate so when pills land on it, they won't just fall out. I also added a few fillets where I saw fit while fixing the problems of version 1. Please note that version 2 does not change the look of the pill case much but changes up the mechanics tremendously. If you want access to the files of version 1 for some reason please add a comment or send me an email (email address located under the "Contact Me" section). Picture of Version 2.0 Assistive Rotating Pill Container Version 2.1 After making Version 2.0 I noticed that some fillets were missing that were in Version 1.0 and 1.1. In Version 2.1 I added the fillets back located on the top and sides of Part 4 and on the side of Part 2. Picture of Version 2.1 Assistive Rotating Pill Container Version 2.2 In Version 2.2 I made the ramp on Part 2 (Where the pills rest on) steeper so the pills can fall out of the pill case easier. Besides that I also added some minor fillets to make some parts of it more smooth. Picture of Version 2.2 Assistive Rotating Pill Container Version 2.3 In version 2.3 two small details were changed. The first one is the the front wall in front of the plate on Part 1 was made taller. This was made taller in a previous version also. The first reason why it was made taller was so it was harder for pills to fall out of. The second reason was so that the text on the front of it would be more visible. Going off of the second reason, the second change that I made was to add "AT" on the front of it as well as a heart. The "AT" stands for Assistive Technology which is the purpose of making this design. Picture of Version 2.3 Assistive Rotating Pill Container

Pre-Assembly Notes The only tools or supplies that you need is some sort of glue or adhesive. Even Elmer's Glue can be used although I would recommend Super Glue if you have any because it will be easier to use. Hot glue is also another decent choice but make sure to not use too much of it. Step 1 For Step 1, have Part 1 set down onto your work table. Take Part 2 and place it on top of Part 1 so that the extrusion go into the hole in the middle of Part 2 as seen in the picture below. You should notice that Part 2 can spin around on top of Part 1. Make sure to NOT add any glue in this first part of the assembly. Step 2 With Part 2 already on Part 1 you are now going to do the same with Part 3. Part 3 should go right into Part 2. The bottom extrusion on Part 3 should fit nicely into the hole on the top extrusion of Part 1. The outside circular walls of Part 3 should go in between the inner walls of Part 2 and the outer posts of Part 2. The top of Part 3 should not extend further than the top of Part 2. Once you have it in place you can remove it so you can apply glue or adhesive in Step 3. Step 3 After taking out Part 3, apply a small amount of glue or adhesive on the bottom extrusion of Part 3. Refer to the picture below. You do not want to add to much glue, otherwise it will also stick to Part 2. No glue should get onto Part 2 because it must be able to rotate freely. Once the glue or adhesive is applied, you can place Part 3 back into Part 2 making sure it fits nicely back into place. If you have chosen to use hot glue make sure Part 3 goes all the way down because like I said earlier, the top of Part 3 should not extend further than the top of Part 2. Note: The face of Part 3 that is colored red indicates the spot that glue or adhesive must be applied. Step 4 Now, take Part 4 (the only remaining one) and place it onto Part 2. It doesn't matter which way the part is facing because all of its seven extrusions are the same. The bottom extrusions of Part 4 should fit into the indents on the top posts of Part 2. Please note that it may be a little loose and that it is okay for it to be. Once you have it in place you can remove it so you can apply glue or adhesive in the final step (Step 5). Step 5 After removing Part 4, you will be using your glue or adhesive on Part 4 to make it stick to Part 2. You will be applying it to the very bottom of the extrusions and the insides part of it on Part 4. Please refer to the picture below. You can apply a decent amount of glue or adhesive on the inside part of the extrusion but don't use too much on the bottom of it to avoid it from oozing out. If you chose to use hot glue than not much glue will be needed for the bottom or side of the extrusion. Note: The faces of Part 4 that is colored red indicates the spots that glue or adhesive must be applied. Manual Using the Assistive Rotating Pill Container is very simple. Simply rotating the pill container by moving Part 2 or Part 4 clockwise until the next day of the week comes up in the gap. Once the pills fall out onto the extruded plate you can grab and take them. To refill all you have to do is drop the pills into the top of the day's container. Note: If you have any questions or concerns with the assembly please refer to the "Contact Me" section in the description.

Any material that you use on this should be perfectly fine although I wouldn't recommend the use of super flexible plastics because some parts may be bent out of shape over time. One suggestion I have for the material is to make Part 3 out of clear plastic. This will allow you to easily see into the pill case and it makes it look a lot better than the just plain plastic color. If you are considering using clear plastic please take a look at the picture below to take a look at how it would look with the clear plastic. Picture of Version 2.2 Assistive Rotating Pill Container

My first contribution will of course have to be my Engineering II teacher. He's the one who introduced the class to use as well as have us enter the contest and make our own designs. He also printed out my first design (Version 1.0) which turned out to have some major design flaws to it. He then helped me out with giving me tips on certain things which is when I began to redesign a lot of the flaws. My second contribution is my school because they have been continuing to support the engineering classes as well as the new Tech Ninja class. Finally, my last contribution is to Solidworks. Solidworks is an amazing software that allows you to build unbelievable designs. I would have never been able to create anything like this without Solidworks.

If you have any ideas on how the design could be improved, questions on anything, or anything else please contact me. You can leave a comment or if you need a quick response send me an email at: [email protected]

title: Bosch cordless drill internal plug (connects with external battery)

description.text:
• This is a plugin for a big number of Bosch tools (7.2 to 14.4 volt).
    Mine is a Bosch PSR 14.4 volt VES-2 from 1996.
    Don't know about the socket of the later introduced 18 volt tools.
  • It replaces my died NiCd-battery using an external NiCd battery pack attached via its loader.
    The plug can be used even with some tools made in China on the cheap (even common 18 volt batteries). Check the connectors, blades/pins and the socket layout first.
    .
    The drill can be powered from external sorces i.e 3d party batteries or car battery chargers now.
    .
    Some soldering and extra tinkering required.
    This is the plug only.
    • -The files: choose one of your liking.
  • The first rev requires you to put two holes by hand.
  • The v2 has this fixed plus some minor cosmetic changes.
    • -The required parts:
  • 2x screws, (selflocking) nuts M4x16 (small heads)
  • 2x screws , (selflocking) nuts M4x40
  • some scrap material makes the tension retainer and a mounting plate if you wish
  • red/black wiring LY10 or similar (1.5mm2), slightly thicker might work too
  • strip of sheet metal (9x40x0.5-1mm), taken from a binder clip

Follow the pics please.
  • Start inspecting your drill.
  • Check the shape of the socket, compare it with my files.
    It has to have a symmetrical shape with two channels.
    Otherwise this thing will not fit wo. modifying the files.
    .
  • Modify the lower part first. It requires to put two holes (ca 2mm dia) next to the short screw to giude the wires through. Fixed with updated files now.
  • Make the contact blades from the metal sheet strip.
  • Clean them. Remove the dirt and paint if there is any.
  • Bend the strip (2x) to l-shape put the contacts through the small opening slots of the lower part.
  • Cut the wire to the desired length. Feed them through the parts
  • Bend the wire ends to a ring shape, put some solder on if you can.
  • Feed the short screws from the middle parts top side through the ringshaped wire ends now.
  • Put the bottom part against the wires
  • Stack the midplate with the lower plate.
  • Put the nuts on (from the lower part bottom side) and tighten the (selflocking) nuts.
  • Put the upper part against the screwed together parts.
  • Feed the long screws trough all the parts.
  • Mount the (selflocking) nuts.
    .
    A small gap may remain depending on the wire thicknes you have used.
    IMHO this is the only thing you can run into a dimensional related problem.
    The lower and mid part clamp the wires against the blades inbetween. If you have choosen the wire to thin it will not get safe contact with the blades.
    .
  • Put the assembly next to your power source.
  • Check the wiring, no shorts please , all leads are conductive.
  • Put power on, check the cabled plug using a meter.
  • Preferable power a lamp or similar before attaching it to the drill.
    .
  • If all is fine put on the tension retainer and a mount plate you have to make as you like on the drill.
    .
  • Next to the electrics. This is no guide, be creative.
    I have used the battery charger of a cheap 18 volt cordless drill.
    I have opend it and put the red wire to the positive pole, the black to the negative.
    .
    -Important:
  • Check the polarity ALLWAYS.
  • if your drill has some electronics within:
  • check the power source, the max. voltage must not exceed the operating range of the usualy internaly used battery.

title: Printed single roof for double Playmobil 4491 rabbit pen

description.text:
We have two Playmobil rabbit pens (Hasenstall in German), which can be connected together, but only one roof, covering only one half of the pens. Of course, such a situation is not acceptable when one has a 3d printer available. Therefore I took the opportunity to prove that the 3d printer can print something useful (besides the usual printer enhancements and calibration pieces).  
The new roof form-fits quite well onto the connected-together rabbit pens.

The scad file is mostly parametric, so you can change the roof dimensions, number of planks, size of gaps etc. if you want.  
The stl was printed in silver PLA, 3mm with the following slicer settings: layer height 0.4mm, single outline, 25% infill, one solid bottom and one solid top layer.  
In the first layer (=top of roof), there are gaps to simulate the planks. Therefore, in the second layer, a lot of bridging will occur. However, this shouldn't cause a problem, because the bridging gap is only 1.2mm (Parameter P13 in the scad file).  
The silver PLA looks quite like the silver plastic Playmobil has used for the doors of the pen.

This is a simple, yet powerfull, spool holder for the Makerbot Replicator 2.
It is designed to just clip-on on top of the printer, under the lip of the "roof".
The 3 rods is 12mm brass tubing, which slides into the holes of the feet and top hooks. No fastening needed. The crossbar is press fitted in the hooks. The standing rods are have a 20degree angle backwards for stability. Mounted with the hooks forward to have the center of gravity above the mounting position. The spool bearing adapters are made in two halfs, bolted together with 3mm bolts. The adapters are designed to hold spools with inner diameter 52 up to 56mm on one side, and 32mm if you turn them(Pic 5&6). If you make 3 spool adapter sets, they can hold both a 32mm and 52-56mm spool.
My adapters warped a bit under printing, so thy have a perfect pressfit with the spools. Parts list:
  • 3pcs 12mm tube/rod length optional(mine 3x40cm)
  • 2pcs ball bearings Type: 6301 2RS Measurement: 12x37x12mm
  • 4pcs 3mm bolts and nuts.
    • Printed:
  • 2pcs Spool foot
  • 2pcs Spool top
  • 4pcs Spool bearing adapters
    • Designed in Autodesk Inventor( part files in the .rar) Any comments and improvements are welcome ;)

All parts printed with: 3 shells
35% infill
layer height: 0.25mm Spool fot printed on the side
Spool top printed on the flat side down
Spool bearing adapter standing(half moon).

DVD player wall mount My media center is a NUC running openelec, and is hidden away behind the TV. Nice and simple. Whenever I have had the need for a DVD player, I have attached an external DVD drive. I have now made this wall mount bracket for the DVD drive, so it can also be hidden away behind the TV. My DVD drive is a LG GP08LU10:
http://www.lg.com/us/burners-drives/lg-GP08LU10-external-dvd-burner I had a few problems while printing. Main issue was that the bracket was bigger than I had expected, so I had not applied glue on a big enough area. I started the print and went for dinner, and when I came back most of the support material had broken off. I anyway decided to let the print finish, so I would have something to measure on. But to my big surprice, first try was close to perfect, so have decided that I don't need to print another one of this. It's anyway hidden behind the TV and nobody will see. The version I printed was the alpha version that I uploaded. It is just slightly longer than what is needed, but due to the rubber feed on the drive, the drive really sticks nicely to the wall. I have also uploaded a beta version. Note that I have not tested the beta version my self, but if I was to print another one of these, I would make the beta version. If anybody tries the beta version, I would like to know. And if the beta works I will delete the alpha.
Rob Fokused

title: Easy Hex Thermoform Bracelet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This simple bracelet prints as a flat string of hexagons in less than 12 minutes. Boil some water while you're waiting and then heat and bend the print into a bracelet that custom-fits your wrist! Sizes from XS to XL are included; each differs only by the number of hexagons in the model. The idea for designing a bracelet that you heat and bend after printing was inspired by the bracer instructions in Gyrobot's fantastic Flexy-Finger Prothesis model. =====

This design and all associated pictures and files are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial Share Alike license. If you want to use designs, images, or files outside of the terms of this license, please email [email protected].

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm works well for this model

It only takes a minute to shape the bracelet after printing:
  • Add very hot water to a container and then submerge the bracelet strip.
  • Poke the strip a bit with a fork and you'll find that it is very flexible and soft after just a couple of seconds.
  • Pull the strip out with the fork and immediately form it into a rough curve. (The water will be hot but the bracelet cools very quickly.)
  • To refine the shape, dip parts of the bracelet back into the hot water and then bend them into shape.﻿

comments.text: Will it work in PLA?
comments.author: nschaupp

comments.text: Yes, in fact PLA is perfect. If you put it in just-done-boiling water, the PLA will get very soft in just a couple of seconds, and you can bend and form it as many times as you like.  (ABS won't get soft enough to bend at that temperature, though)

A diminutive staircase style Marblevator featuring knobs at both ends for clockwise, counter clockwise, left or right hand operation. After seeing the prototype with multicolored steps, my wife thought "Rainbow Roll" (sushi reference) was a better name; I'm sticking with Baby Steps. Uses 8mm (5/16") ball bearings as marbles. Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yeF4z9jjIDE. Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Study "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
Print all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".  I added hold down disks to "Base.stl" to assist in minimizing warping, carefully remove them after printing.
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.  The return track, especially where it enters the landing area, will need to be carefully trimmed, filed, sanded, etc. in order to remove the striation artifacts of .2mm 3D printing.
Assemble as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
Feel free to comment if you have questions.
Hope you like it!

We have two types of doors in our school and we want to be able to lock them quickly without using a key in case there is a sub. Our solution were creating two ABS plastic parts that we printed ourselves on our 3D printer. The door always remains locked but opens when the part is in a certain position. If there is an intruder, a person could slightly open the door and slide the part into the locked position. The locks in action can be viewed at...https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dNxqyoSrQRc The original roller lock version might stick out too much. We've had several break when students get their backpacks hooked on them or something. I just uploaded a left and right smaller version that seems to be working better.

author: fstreff

title: HICTOP Prusa i3 - lead screw guide (wobbling mitigation)

description.text:
The HICTOP prusa i3 lead screws that come with the kit have acrylic plates on the top that is "supposed" to keep the smooth rods and lead screws in position. But the lead screws slowly grind the acrylic over time and cause a lot of noise.
I came up with a small idea to put the lead screw in place with a help of a ball bearing support.
I wasnt able to get the accurate dimensions of the acrylic parts (the company refused to release). But this works fine.
if someone happens to have the dimensions please share.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1-0.2

Infill:

minimum 70%

Notes: Try printing this with a stiff/rigid material : PLA high infill or Carbon fiber PLA etc Print with the thicker side on the base so that the bearing cavity doesnt have support.

comments.text: Hey, Looks like a solid part, but you should not rigidly position the tops of the threaded rod. You are not confining them at 3 points (bottom, the x carriage, and the top). This will introduce more wobble into your printer. Only the ground rods should be confined rigidly. They provide the positioning of the x carriage. This design will cause the X carriage to wobble with the Z screws.

A home fit for a bird king. This castle prints in 3 parts and assembles with no need for additional tools.  The peg and hole fit between top and bottom allows for easy removal of the top. The base is meant to mounted to a post or placed on a pedestal.

I can verify that the design is printable and am currently in the process of painting mine. I will post photos once it is finished. Assembly:
  • Insert Perch through small center whole in the part named "castle_bird2".
  • Place Top half of castle on top of pegs on the part named "castle_bird1".
  • Press fit each peg in its corresponding hole
  • Enjoy!
    • Print Settings: Layer Height: .15mm
    Shells: 3
    Infill: 15%
    Material: PLA
    Printer: Makerbot Replciator 2
    Scale: 78%
    Speed: 120mm/s (Sailfish Firmware)
    Temperature: 200°C

author: Redstar1978

title: Makerbot Z18 Filament Spool Holder - Strut Type

description.text:
This spool holder is designed to fit tightly onto the back corners of a Z18 (with top cover removed). After you push them tightly in place, they will be rigid like extensions of your printer.
This structure is optimized to withstand vertical loading and have a high fundamental frequency (like on bridges), so that, you can hang up to 10 spools of filament on it, and still carry your printer around without taking them off. After you start using these, you will not have to worry about weight or vibration. And of course, you will prevent filament jams :) 
In this design, top cavity for your "filament rack" is a 6,5mm (1/4 inch) wide slit, so you can easily insert/remove a metal bar of up to 6mm thickness. I'm using an aluminium T-profile that I found around. You can modify the top cavity to fit any rack you want to use, as long as it is strong enough to carry all your filaments.

This is a knob that I created to help people turn on lamps. Lots of lamps use those little black nubs that you have to turn to turn them on and off. They can be difficult to turn on and off sometimes and would be nearly impossible to use for someone with limited hand control. The lamp knob simply press fits onto the lamp and allows users to easily turn on and off their lamps. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PVuUML8c7IA&feature=youtu.be

I bought a Linkmount for my cell phone. I also had an old suction cup/goose neck from a "Bell" windshield phone holder. I made an adapter that connects the Linkmount Simplemount magnet holder to the goose neck. Look at www.linkmount.com for the linkmount.

Skids for the ZMR250 frame including double motor protection.
Just like user Judar (from the source file) I had problems with the moist ground and getting mud in my motors. The side panels will protect your motors from dirt and also functions as a bumper when crashing into something hard.
It was an easy step to add the legs to lift the quad somewhat more from the (wet) grass.

I made a new version which is lighter, stronger, sleeker and way better to print! I included two versions for respectively 16-12mm and 19-16mm holes. The 16-12mm will fit the DYS1806 motors, the 19-16mm should fit 2204 and 2206 motor.
Make sure to rotate the object (135°) in your slicer software in a way that it stands on the one flat surface and it will be printed clean and strong! The _thick files are as requested by davidjormi, with 33% thicker walls. The normal version is strong enough for me in PLA with 20% infill, so please let me know when you print these versions and how they fit!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes: For the version 2s, make sure that you align the model on its flat surface.

A Birdhouse in the form of a tilted cube  
Three panels make up the roof to resist the rain, while the structure beneath is an open lattice that allows wind and water to pass through, also branches can be placed through the lattice to give multiple perches for the birds.   
there are holes to tie string through on the corners of the roof, and when all three corners are tied to a treebranch there should not be any twisting or rotating of the birdhouse.  
I built this at an angle and method that hopefully does not require support material, though I have not yet tested.

author: siman007

description.text:
We made a tugboat. It goes to set #2. You take a rubber band put it between the two prongs and  then you take the X and wind it towards the boat. 
This model was designed during an after school 3D printing club by 5-7 graders.

ThingiBoat I designed it by first thinking of what would be cool. So I thought it would be cool to finally make a boat for the 3D printing community. I started with a rough sketch that sort of looked like a coffin/popsicle with two sticks coming out the end. Then I had to find a way to power it, which was a rubber band and a extra circle so it would be able to be tugged along with the tow truck.

https://youtu.be/COaiLH__62c idea comes from the net and:
http://www.heise.de/make/inhalt/2015/5/16/ (german make magazine edition, current issue) parts:
arduino nano
uln2803 driver (you could use 3 transistor instead)
rgb stripe (60 pieces per meter, using 21pieces on 35cm cut)
halleffect sensor (TLE4905L) and a neodym magnet (3x2mm) for sync
motor comes from an old cd-rom drive
rtc module with ds1307 23.12.2016:
just added (base) case plans for lasercut (3mm material)

mount for 1kg spool if anyone wants a larger spool mount just leave a comment on the weight and size of the spool Tested with up to .3 layer hight and .4 infil .PRT file is added if you want to adjust to fit your frame perfectly, a digital caliper is reccomended. UGS NX 7.5 was used to design. my laser cut pieces came all oversized and hardly fit togeather so my dimensions may be oversized or undersized depending on your particular frame. the rod is 8mm but any rod will do. a thickness of 15mm is reccomended to eliminate virtical rotation slippage, but works well down to 4mm.. infill can be as low as .2-.3 but thickness should really be around 15mm in that case. total distance from rear of spool to rear of top frame is 18.5 cm
total distance from absolute rear of frame to rear of spool is 8.5 cm will update in the future to eliminate stress maximums but current model works like a charm

comments.text: Thanks for creating and uploading this, it works great. I used a longer rod so that both the mounts are out to the edges where there is more support structure. Very sturdy, looks great, and doesn't stick out too far.
